body:
I am fine with homosexuals as long as they don't push their agenda onto others - which is what they now do. 
It seems that most gay males I knew had very odd relationships with their father, who, in most cases, was very distant from kids and wife. Its as though these gay males are still chasing after the love and attention of their father years later.  Its a creepy, rather Freudian idea, but that is what I've seen. 
I'm not as sure about gay females...though it seems the more masculine gay females have had more admiration for male figures in their childhoods - almost an envy mixed with fear. They seem to detest and resent their mother's weakness and lack of responsibility.
Arm-chair psychologist...oops

body:
It is a mental illness and not all mental illnesses can be cured.  I certainly don't think it should be encouraged and would feel myself a failure if I had a kid turn out gay.  But, fully condemning is too much.  Perhaps we should stop it before it starts by making it socially permissible for many people to **NOT** have kids.  So many parents have families merely because they fear society's disapproval if they don't.  Those parents or married people never really wanted it, but felt pressured. Neither of my parents had any business having kids. It sure seems that both dislike kids.
So, I think gay people are really just victims of bad parenting and later in life want to punish society by beating us over the heads with their gayness, shoving it down our throats.  Most gay people are extremely hurt, **BITTER** people.  And, trannies are the absolute worst.  Even many gays think trannies are mental fruitcakes and they avoid them.

parent.body: we'll have to disagree on all of that.  a loving, attentive parent builds a kid's self-esteem and is an active role model and teacher. I believe we cannot control the seas or winds, but we can control our sails and the upkeep of our ship and crew.  We have more control than we acknowledge.  Instead of seeing that as 'shame', you could see it as an advantage - that we are able to avert pain more than many admit....and I find that a *hopeful* concept.

body:
well, if it *is* DNA, they have no right to feel either proud or ashamed of it nor should others ask them to feel either of those ways.  No one on this planet has control over their DNA. Shame and pride should be reserved for things we as individuals did all by ourselves - instead of accidents of birth. 
I guess there are some cases where DNA played a role, but I still think most are nurture, not nature.
Sad about that boarding school upbringing.  I'd rather cut my leg off than let my young child grow up away from me or his/her family. Over age 12...maybe....if the kid BEGGED me.

body: I think you're underestimating nature unfortunately. Some of my friends constantly make god-like accomplishments fairly easily, often without even thinking about it, while I struggle to even do one thing 1/4 as well in much more time. We've all had the same ambition and experience, but our results are vastly different. I feel like nurture is only about 25% of the story, the vast majority of it is how you were born. It's been proven that adopted children are *much* more like their biological parents than their adoptive ones, even if they've never met the former. This world is unfair shit.

body:
I've read and agree with that study about DNA and adoptive families/biology.  Life seems unfair and often is.  Just remember that some people are born with lower IQs, some with uglier faces, some with evil parents, some born into dangerous neighborhoods...There are many types of unfairness.  That beautiful little girl may be getting raped by her step brother once a week or that great baseball player in high school may get beaten up by his dad if he strikes out in a game. 
People envy Ted Turner, but I read his biography and knew a woman who worked for him: he was placed in a boarding home at age 7.  Fricking SEVEN!  What asswipe of a parent puts their kids elsewhere at that tender age?! So, his dad being rich didn't help his childhood much.  Later his dad committed suicide and later Ted himself struggled with alcoholism and suicidal thoughts. My point is that we always think the other side has it better.  Sometimes it *does*, but oftentimes people don't wear their weakness on their sleeves. *YOU* might think they have it *better*, but *better* is subjective.  Look at all of the trust fund kids ODing and those celebrities, too. They cannot handle reality and so try to drown it out with drugs.  From afar it may seem like they are partying and having fun, but they are trying to escape reality. There are 2 sides to every coin.  Fame and fortune bring out jealous people who want to take away what you have.

body:
I have a gay friends, and I don't really  have a problem with their lifestyle. I'm actually going to be in a gay wedding in 2022, as a "brides" maid. But at the same time, I see where you're coming from. 

I've had lesbian friends and one of them admitted to me, she had been severely molested/raped as a child. She wasn't a lesbian because she was born a lesbian--she was a lesbian because she feared men. 

Lesbians are the most promiscuous and unfaithful people I have ever met. More so than gay men or straight men. That gives me a lot of pause. Why? Why can't you focus on one person? What is the mental process? I have less respect, oddly, for lesbians than gay men. A lot of them aren't "okay" mentally. Gay Men are actually more mentally stable than lesbians. 

At the same time, I've known gay people who are just...gay. It's like asking someone....when did you realize you were straight? There is no answer to that question. You either are or you aren't, for some people. Homosexuality has existed since the beginning of time immortal. Alexander the Great was bi-sexual. The Spartans were gay/ bi-sexual. Studies have shown that some people are genetically hardwired to be gay. For example, the cross between right and left brain is physically larger in women--and gay men. There is a physical, genetic reason that cannot be helped, or "cured". 

As you said, I have no problem with gay people as long as they don't push their "agenda" onto others. I believe that in today's world, there are several different types of homosexual---

Those that are simply born that way and can't help it, something in the genetic process went "wrong" and that's just how they are. If we can experience physical "birth defects" then we can also experience physiological "brain" defects we can't help. Some humans are wired differently. I believe this is the case with my friend who's wedding I will be fully supporting. 

Those that are gay because of some mental/physical trauma in their life, whether thats a dysfunctional parent or molestation/rape. Perhaps a part of them can't bear the thought of being with someone who resembles, in any way, the person who hurt them the most. 

I'm okay with both these types of homosexuals, and support them fully in their very difficult life path. 

And those that are now suddenly gay because it's the "cool" thing to be. Because it gives them social points or they think it makes them "hot". Those people are attention seeking and mentally unhinged. I'm not okay with them because their gayness doesn't come from an honest place. Its the equivalent of SJW social climbing. These are the people that are 'forcing' their lifestyle on others, who feel the need to "preach" and push to justify themselves and their choices. And for these people, it is a choice. These are the ones we need to be wary of. They're the actress who is suddenly Trans for attention and social points. 

At some point I think we need to differentiate between the three types and have compassion and understanding for the first two, and repudiate the third as mentally unstable....not lump them all together as one.

I'm not as sure about gay females...though it seems the more masculine gay females have had more admiration for male figures in their childhoods - almost an envy mixed with fear. They seem to detest and resent their mother's weakness and lack of responsibility.
Arm-chair psychologist...oops

body:
> I think you need to find out how YOU are uniquely special

That's the thing, I'm not. I'm just ok at everything and that's as far as I will ever get. I have no strengths or advantages of my own. Even if I do, which I haven't seen any of yet, it must be something I hate doing. Yet these other people are automatically perfect, and I mean *perfect* at not just one or two things, but nearly *everything*. The stuff I've been obsessed with for years, they will blow me away just starting out or barely being interested in it. And I'm not even good enough at anything to accomplish barely anything decent at all, let alone with almost no faults at all in such little amount of time with such little experience.

body:
>How would that be your problem? 

The fact that you're even asking me this question shows just how far we've fallen as a civilization.

Believe it or not, but most normal people don't want their family members to join the LGBTQIA+ [lack of] community because it's a total freak show full of mentally ill and dysgenic weirdos. 

And so asking me why my family members becoming gay would be my problem is like asking me why I should care if my younger sister became a twerking lesbian pothead rather than a married mom, or why I should care if my dad divorced my mom and started butt-fucking a different Asian twink every single week that he matched up with on Grinder. 

Obviously the life decisions of my family members, and the larger society around me, affects my mental well-being and quality of life. It's common fucking sense. Why do I even have to increasingly explain the obvious these days?

Oh, right - because we live in a God-forsaken progressive PissWorld.
